description: Hennig Brand discovers phosphorus, sparking interest in the study of elements.
Antoine Lavoisier publishes a list of 33 elements, grouped into gases, metals, nonmetals, and earths.
John Dalton proposes the atomic theory, stating that elements consist of indivisible atoms with characteristic atomic weights.
Johann Wolfgang Döbereiner observes the Law of Triads, the first attempt to group elements based on their properties.
Jöns Jacob Berzelius introduces the modern system of chemical notation with one- or two-letter symbols for elements.
August Kekulé proposes the valence theory, laying the foundation for understanding chemical bonding and the periodicity of elements.
Stanislao Cannizzaro's presentation on atomic weights at the Karlsruhe Congress leads to the acceptance of atomic weights as a basis for the classification of elements.
John Newlands proposes the Law of Octaves, which arranges elements in increasing atomic weight with similar properties appearing every eighth element.
Dmitri Mendeleev presents his first periodic table, arranging elements by atomic weight and leaving gaps for yet-to-be-discovered elements.
Mendeleev refines his periodic table, predicting the properties of undiscovered elements such as gallium, scandium, and germanium.
Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay discover argon, leading to the identification of a new group of elements called noble gases.
J.J. Thomson discovers the electron, leading to the development of the first models of atomic structure.
Max Planck proposes the quantum theory, which eventually leads to the understanding of electron energy levels in atoms.
Ernest Rutherford discovers the atomic nucleus, refining the model of atomic structure.
Henry Moseley establishes the concept of atomic number, providing a more accurate basis for the arrangement of elements in the periodic table.
Niels Bohr develops the electron configuration model, which further explains the periodicity of elements.
Louis de Broglie proposes the wave-particle duality of electrons, a key concept in the development of quantum mechanics.
Erwin Schrödinger develops the wave equation, providing a mathematical description of electron behavior in atoms.
Friedrich Hund and Robert S. Mulliken develop the concept of electron
James Chadwick discovers the neutron, leading to a better understanding of atomic structure and isotopes.
Glenn T. Seaborg and his team synthesize plutonium and later discover other transuranium elements, leading to the expansion of the periodic table with the actinide series.
Glenn T. Seaborg proposes the actinide concept, which distinguishes the actinide series as a separate group in the periodic table.
Discovery of more synthetic elements, filling in gaps in the periodic table.
Neil Bartlett synthesizes the first noble gas compound, xenon hexafluoroplatinate, challenging the assumption that noble gases are inert.
The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) establishes a standardized periodic table, which forms the basis for the modern periodic table.
Ongoing research on superheavy elements and their stability, exploring the limits of the periodic table.
Discovery and naming of the last four elements of the seventh period (nihonium, moscovium, tennessine, and oganesson), completing the current periodic table.
